Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

It would be great if college sports could live up to the ideal of scholars who compete as a hobby and as a way to show pride in their universities, but this is clearly not the case in reality.  College is viewed as a stepping stone by a lucky few who feel that they have what it takes to make a career out of playing sports.  They are generally given special treatment by professors who view the sports teams as a vital part of the university's balance sheet, and often are not held to the same standards as other students.  

And we should not judge the players themselves too harshly for this system, because they did not make the rules.  The NCAA and the colleges require them to work more than full time at their sport, all for the good of the school.  They do not have time to pursue a full-time education and to work to support themselves.

The NCAA's rules against paying these players are designed to protect the interests of the universities and the NCAA itself, not the players.  This means that college sports attracts only those who have the financial wherewithal to attend college while essentially doing nothing but training and competing in sports, all for the hoped-for reward of a professional sports contract after graduation.  This is not what the college athletic ideal hoped for, and we should stop pretending that those ideals are being upheld.

If we accept reality, on the other hand, and pay athletes for their service, then they can pursue their education either part time or after they have competed to their own satisfaction.  As it currently stands, however, we are just forcing student athletes to work for their institutions for nothing more than a vague promise of future riches.

No matter how you look at it, this is either a violation of labor laws, or it is a violation of the NCAA's stated ideal of the scholarly athlete.  Nobody can, and nobody should, accept the system in its current form.  Giving students housing allowances and other forms of compensation is just a disguised form of payment, so why do we pretend that a paycheck would change anything?

I contend that the college-athletics system has evolved, and that if people are happy with the way it is set up, then the employees who are keeping it going should be paid fairly for their efforts.  If any coaches or talent scouts disagree, then I would invite them to give up their salaries and instead work for the same promises that they give to their students.
